qas.question: Who wanted the British to keep using machine guns in World War I?
The military was not allowed to use anything that was bigger than what?
What was determined to be the smallest effective round in 1935?

answers.text: an impact fused 2 lb HE shell

qas.question: What was lighter than the water-cooled pom-pom?
What is the Kerrison Predictor's official name?

context: Until this time the British, at <a0_0>RAF<a0_0/> insistence, continued their World War I use of machine guns, and introduced twin MG mountings for AAAD. The army was forbidden from considering anything larger than <a1_0>.50-inch<a1_0/>. However, in 1935 their trials showed that the minimum effective round was <a2_0>an impact fused 2 lb HE shell<a2_0/>. The following year they decided to adopt the Bofors 40 mm and a twin barrel Vickers 2-pdr (40 mm) on a modified naval mount. <a3_0>The air-cooled Bofors<a3_0/> was vastly superior for land use, being much lighter than the water-cooled pom-pom, and UK production of the Bofors 40 mm was licensed. <a4_0>The Predictor AA No 3<a4_0/>, as the Kerrison Predictor was officially known, was introduced with it.
